Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Central Washington University (CWU) and five community colleges (Edmonds Community College, Highline Community College, Green River Community College, Wenatchee Valley College, and Yakima Valley Community College) are implementing a Phase I NSF Noyce Scholarship Program for the purpose of recruiting and educating STEM majors and STEM professionals to become science and mathematics teachers. Over five years, 44 SMART Scholars are being prepared to teach, and 70 freshman or sophomore SMART interns are participating in research or academic service learning experiences to interest them in teaching. High priority is placed on recruiting students that reflect the student populations found at the 16 high needs partnering school districts, and partnering community colleges who, as teachers, will provide good role models for the students at these schools. After graduating, Scholars are mentored by both a STEM educational college faculty member and a teacher mentor through the SMART Scholar Induction Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In response to a regional and nationwide teacher shortage in secondary science and mathematics, Central Washington University (CWU) in partnership with five community colleges initiated a NSF Noyce Scholars Program to recruit and train STEM majors and STEM professionals to become science and mathematics teachers in high need schools.

Intellectual Merit - The CWU Noyce Scholarship Program provided activities and experiences that supported scholars and affiliates in preparing for and transitioning into a science or mathematics teaching career in a high need school. Focused recruitment of underrepresented students from community colleges with paid faculty advisors resulted in a 44% overall increase in the average annual number of minority secondary mathematics and science teachers in the five years post-Noyce as compared to five years pre-Noyce. Overall, the annual average post-Noyce vs. pre-Noyce production of secondary science and mathematics teachers increased by 12%. Scholars and affiliates contributed to the body of knowledge in science, mathematics, science education, and mathematics education through dissemination of scholarly works produced in faculty mentored research.

Broader Impacts – Thirty-four scholars were prepared to teach science or mathematics with four additional scholars in the pipeline (n = 38), 31 are currently filling teaching positions in high need schools. Scholars and affiliates gained specific knowledge and skills to enhance their ability to work with underrepresented students, thus providing support for diversifying the future pool of STEM-ready students entering college. Participating CWU and K-12 faculty in science and mathematics improved their ability to incorporate strategies promoting inclusiveness in their teaching. Forty-two affiliates applied their early career knowledge to academic service learning and research opportunities, gaining valuable practical experience Twenty-two affiliates pursued careers in teaching; 10 are working on certification and 12 are certified teachers. Of the 25 affiliates who completed the program in time to apply to the Scholar Program, nine applied and were accepted.

The CWU Noyce Program had three overarching goals: increase the number of highly qualified math and science teachers, increase the number of underrepresented science and math teachers, and increase the retention of science and math teachers. Results were positive for all goals.

Thirty-eight STEM majors were funded to become science and mathematics secondary school teachers in high need schools. A five year average of pre-Noyce mathematics and science teacher graduates compared to a five year average beginning with the first Noyce graduating class reveals an overall annual average increase in the production of science and mathematics teachers at CWU of 12%.

The CWU Noyce Program funded 12 (31.6%) STEM students from underrepresented ethnicities who trained to become mathematics and science teachers. This resulted in a 44% increase in minority representation of certified science and math teachers overall at CWU.

The Noyce Affiliate Program, designed as a recruiting tool, allowed high achieving science and mathematics students to have early, engaging teaching or research experiences. A total of 42 freshmen and sophomores were supported as affiliates, 23.8% of whom were underrepresented. Of the students who could do their experience at a partner community college (academic year experiences), 47.4% did. Though research experiences were initially offered, recognizing the importance of scientific inquiry in the training of teachers, it became clear that the affiliates were not crystalizing their interest in teaching through these experiences despite explicit discussions about how their experiences would benefit them in the classroom. For this reason students were advised to take advantage of the opportunity to get experience teaching. Over half of the students (52.4%) who participated in the Affiliate Program entered a science or mathematics teaching program at CWU. The Affiliate Program proved to be an excellent strategy for recruiting minority students into teaching programs as 70% of the underrepresented students that participated in the Affiliate Program entered a science or mathematics teaching program at CWU.

Of the 33 students funded by Noyce that have completed their certification, 31 (94%) of them are currently teaching mathematics or science in high need schools at the middle or high school level, 12 have completed their service requirement and 100% of those continue to teach in high need schools. The first of the Noyce scholars to graduate have completed their fourth year of teaching. 

The interview, survey, and focus group qualitative data collected, analyzed and reported by the external evaluator also indicate positive outcomes for our Noyce Program. The students were uniformly pleased with the program especially the year-long internship and Noyce scholar seminar. In reponse, the Noyce team led the effort on campus to adopt the University of Texas-Austin UTeach program. The team received a large state grant and committed resources from CWU to collaboratively adapt the UTeach model for Washington State teacher preparation requirements. The Noyce year-long internship and the induction program provided a solid foundation for convincing faculty and administrators to support the adoption.


Last Modified: 12/30/2016
Modified by: Martha J Kurtz

Intellectual Merit - The CWU Noyce Scholarship Program provided activities and experiences that supported scholars and affiliates in preparing for and transitioning into a science or mathematics teaching career in a high need school. Focused recruitment of underrepresented students from community colleges with paid faculty advisors resulted in a 44% overall increase in the average annual number of minority secondary mathematics and science teachers in the five years post-Noyce as compared to five years pre-Noyce. Overall, the annual average post-Noyce vs. pre-Noyce production of secondary science and mathematics teachers increased by 12%. Scholars and affiliates contributed to the body of knowledge in science, mathematics, science education, and mathematics education through dissemination of scholarly works produced in faculty mentored research. The team received a large state grant and committed resources from CWU to collaboratively adapt the UTeach model for Washington State teacher preparation requirements. The Noyce year-long internship and the induction program provided a solid foundation for convincing faculty and administrators to support the adoption.
